node.title: Christmas cash splash expected as Australians raid COVID-19 savings
node.description: Australians are expected to splash much of the cash they stashed during lockdowns on Christmas spending, after October and November sales already recorded big gains.
node.content:
["Despite months of lockdowns, lost incomes and travel restrictions this year, most Australians are expected to splash their stash of cash this Christmas.", "The Commonwealth Bank's Household Spending Intentions (HSI) Index is the highest level its been since just before the COVID-19 pandemic began.", "Its snapshot of people's spending activity, as well as their spending intentions, rose 2.1 per cent in November, to reach 110.3 points.", "It nudges the record high since the index began in 2019, of 111.1 points recorded in December that year.", "The bank's chief economist, Stephen Halmarick, said the data showed\u00a0Australia's\u00a0economic recovery from the most recent east coast lockdowns was\u00a0strong.", "He explained that this was because households that were unable to undertake their normal spending on many services during lockdowns have been stashing away hundreds of billions of dollars in additional savings, compared to pre-COVID levels.", "\"Australians have grown their savings to record levels during the pandemic,\" he observed.", "", "
Shoppers in Sydney's busy Martin Place appear keen to exercise their wallets.(ABC News: John Gunn)
", "
What are people planning to spend their money on?
", "\"The HSI index shows\u00a0a continued and broad-based recovery in consumer spending since the end of lockdowns,\" Mr Halmarick said.", "", "
Commonwealth Bank of Australia chief economist\u00a0Stephen Halmarick says the amount of savings in personal\u00a0bank accounts is unprecedented.(Supplied: CBA)
", "\"While we have seen sharp increases in categories like transport and travel, there is still plenty of room for further growth.\"", "The retail sub-category of the\u00a0index was up 9.6 per cent in November, to be up 5.6 per cent over\u00a0the previous\u00a012 months.", "Retail spending has risen 21 per cent since a\u00a0low point in August, with the largest gains in department stores, clothing, furniture and\u00a0household equipment, electronic stores, household appliances, jewellery and\u00a0watches, as well as\u00a0pet shops.", "\"In a further positive note, it looks like end-of-year celebrations have driven increased spending on cosmetics, tailors and\u00a0alterations, and clothing rentals,\" Mr Halmarick said.", "The biggest increases in the index \u2014\u00a0which combines spending activity with Google Trends \u2014\u00a0were in transport (up 21.5 per cent) and\u00a0travel (up 14.7 per cent).", "And the travel index is up 25 per cent on an annual basis, showing people are ready to pack their bags and take a holiday.", "\"Significantly, the travel spending intentions index is now up 77 per cent\u00a0from the Delta lockdown low of August 2021, but is still 30 per cent\u00a0lower than its pre-Covid levels of November 2019,\" Mr Halmarick said.", "As Australians embark on longed-for holidays, spending is up on\u00a0hotels, motels and resorts, travel agents, airlines, tourist attractions, camper and RVs and their rental, cruise ships, bus lines and airports.", "The transport spending intentions index jumped\u00a021.5 per cent in November.", "
Didn't\u00a0everyone spend\u00a0up big in Black Friday sales?
", "Yes, they did.", "", "
Retailers are offering Black Friday discounts in-store and online.(ABC News: John Gunn)
", "NAB's analysis of merchant transactions\u00a0estimates that Australians spent more than $8 billion across the four days from Black Friday to Cyber Monday.", "It said the promotional holiday beat pre-pandemic records from 2019, with sales up 8 per cent.", "\"Business is absolutely up and running again \u2014 it was great to see people out and about making the most of bargains as well as spending big online,\" wrote Andrew Irvine, group executive for NAB's Business and Private Bank after the sales weekend.", "\"For business, it's a great opportunity try out initiatives before the holiday season, reach out to online customer bases and kick off the lead up to Christmas with strong cashflow.\"", "ANZ senior economist\u00a0Adelaide Timbrell said that,\u00a0while Black Friday sales this year were slightly lower than the 2020 high, retailers had\u00a0benefited from a similar perfect storm of positive factors.", "\"Spending was helped by resilient household incomes and high savings rates through the year, due to lockdown conditions, improvements in consumer confidence through November and a lack of opportunity for international \u2014 and, in many cases, domestic \u2014\u00a0travel,\" she said.", "ANZ found non-food retailing on Black Friday was 2.2 per cent lower than 2020, but still 36 per cent stronger than in 2019.", "Ms Timbrell said\u00a0that fashion sales on Black Friday were stronger than last year, while consumer electronics sales waned a little from their 2020 peak.", "
Spending also jumped after lockdowns ended
", "Even before the frenzy of Black Friday, the lifting of lockdowns was enough to encourage more retail spending.", "October retail trade figures, published by the\u00a0Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) last week, showed a 4.9 per cent increase in turnover, seasonally adjusted.", "", "
Crowds returned to Sydney's Pitt St Mall after lockdown ended in mid-October.(ABC News: John Gunn)
", "It was the strongest monthly rise since Victoria's first lockdown bounce back in November 2020, with retail turnover regaining most of the momentum lost before the Delta outbreak.", "ABS director of quarterly economy wide Statistics Ben James said the picture in New South Wales was also positive after the state came out of its lockdowns recently.", "\"With lockdown ending on October 11, New South Wales sales rose 13.3 per cent, returning to the levels seen in the months immediately prior to the Delta outbreak, while Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory remain below pre-Delta levels,\" Mr\u00a0James said.", "Victoria's lockdown ended on October 22 and its spending for the month rose 3.0 per cent.", "The Australian Capital Territory's lockdown ended on October 15 and spending there rose 20.2 per cent.", "Which means there's probably still capacity for people to keep shopping \u2014 something retailers will be hoping for in the lead-up to Christmas."]
